title: Information leakage of private program

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hello team,
I noticed an issue in `Directory` where information of a soft-launched program getting disclosed!

I made this request as an unauthecated user,
```http
GET /programs/search?query█████████&sort=published_at%3Adescending&page=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: hackerone.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:47.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/47.0
Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01
Accept-Language: en-GB,bn;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
DNT: 1
X-CSRF-Token: <redacted>
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Referer: https://hackerone.com/directory?query█████████
Cookie: <redacted>
Connection: close
```

and partial response was,
```
{"id":1913,"url":"/██████████","name":"████","meta":{"bug_count":5,"minimum_bounty":100,"soft_launched":true},"about":"","handle":"██████████","profile_picture":"https://profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com/production/████████","internet_bug_bounty":false}
```
███████

This issue also disclose the **Policy** of that program!
I've attached the policy as text.

####Reproducible Steps:
* Navigate to **[Directory](https://hackerone.com/directory)**
* Search ████
* Result will be,
█████████

You won't see the bug count, policy and base bounty on result. but if you capture the request on BURP response, you'll be able to harvest these information from there! 

Looking forward!

I noticed an issue in Directory where information of a soft-launched program getting disclosed!

I made this request as an unauthecated user,

GET /programs/search?query█████████&sort=published_at%3Adescending&page=1 HTTP/1.1

Connection: close

and partial response was,

{"id":1913,"url":"/██████████","name":"████","meta":{"bug_count":5,"minimum_bounty":100,"soft_launched":true},"about":"","handle":"██████████","profile_picture":"https://profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com/production/████████","internet_bug_bounty":false}

███████

This issue also disclose the Policy of that program!
I've attached the policy as text.

Reproducible Steps:

  • Navigate to Directory
  • Search ████
  • Result will be, █████████

You won't see the bug count, policy and base bounty on result. but if you capture the request on BURP response, you'll be able to harvest these information from there!

Looking forward!

activities.message:
Hi Faisal,

Thank you for your report. We are currently investigating this behavior and will get back to you once we figure out whether this is an actual security vulnerability. The odd thing is that this appears to be specific to the ███████ program.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi Faisal,

Thank you for your report. We are currently investigating this behavior and will get back to you once we figure out whether this is an actual security vulnerability. The odd thing is that this appears to be specific to the ███████ program.

activities.message:
Hi @andrewone,
Thanks for prompt response.
You're right. This exploit works for only one specific semi-launched program only.
Since being an unauthenticated user, i can extract a semi-launched program's `bug_count`, `policy` and `base_bounty` etc information. I'm sure it's a potential security issue.
As unauthenticated users are able to access these information, a fix should be rolled out ASAP.
Looking forward to hear from you guys soon :)
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @andrewone,
Thanks for prompt response.
You're right. This exploit works for only one specific semi-launched program only.
Since being an unauthenticated user, i can extract a semi-launched program's bug_count, policy and base_bounty etc information. I'm sure it's a potential security issue.
As unauthenticated users are able to access these information, a fix should be rolled out ASAP.
Looking forward to hear from you guys soon :)

activities.message:
Hello @faisalahmed,

You stumbled upon a very special program, `██████` announced publicly that they have a private program! You can't access it, but you can see it. I agree the `confidential` label is a bit confusing and we're going to work on better wording.

Thanks for your report and hack on!

Willian
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @faisalahmed,

You stumbled upon a very special program, ██████ announced publicly that they have a private program! You can't access it, but you can see it. I agree the confidential label is a bit confusing and we're going to work on better wording.

Thanks for your report and hack on!

Willian

activities.message:
Hello @wvdv,
Thank your for your reply.

>You stumbled upon a very special program, `███` announced publicly that they have a private program! You can't access it, but you can see it.

First of all, what you've described is a security issue itself. why would i be able to **see** a semi-launched program? isn't it meant to be private?
i didn't just "stumbled upon" on special program who announced they have a private program. 
**I extracted some information of that program, which should've kept private.**
I can gather a list of private program just by Google dork (search with `inurl:security intext:hackerone intext:contact us`, you'll get atleast 7/8 companies who has private program on HackerOne) and there's some other effective ways.
But i can never **see** that program, unless I'm invited to that particular program.

>I agree the `confidential` label is a bit confusing and we're going to work on better wording.

This is not confusing at all. there's a bug behind this behavior, which causing this. what confusing is your response on this report and you need to work better on this.

I'm able to harvest **program policy** of a private (you agreed it's a private program and i can see`soft_launched=true` which ensure it is indeed a private) program, where it describes all of its tiers (tears 1 to 5) and scopes and all. 
I'm able to extract `bug_count` of a private program, where it shows how many bugs got solved. in this case it was **5**
I'm able to see the minimum bounty `base_bounty` of a private program. which is $100 in this case.
And after all these confidential information disclosure you've changed status of this report to **Informative**?

Lets go to HackerOne's [program scope](https://hackerone.com/security) and see what it says, 
> Reports which enumerate already claimed user and program handles. This reveals no sensitive information, regardless of whether the associated profiles are public or private.

True that. only knowing private programs handle reveals no sensitive information. But revealing total bug count, program policy and minimum bounty surely does. these are sensitive information and they should be kept as confidential.

Now lets take a look at this issue to some other kinda similar issues which are fixed and rewarded,

#124611 - Disclosure of private programs that have an "external" page on HackerOne
Issue: Know whether there's a private program exist or not through response.
Disclosed sensitive information: NONE

#118965 - Distinguish EP+Private vs Private programs in HackerOne
Issue: Know whether there's a private program exist or not through response.
Disclosed sensitive information: NONE

#116798 - Private Program Disclosure in /:handle/settings/allow_report_submission.json endpoint
Issue: Know whether there's a private program exist or not through response.
Disclosed sensitive information: NONE

#116032 - Private Program Disclosure in /:handle/reports/draft.json endpoint
Issue: Know whether there's a private program exist or not through response.
Disclosed sensitive information: NONE

#105887 - Know whether private program for company exist or not
Issue: Know whether there's a private program exist or not through response.
Disclosed sensitive information: NONE

#81083 - Internal bounty and swag details disclosed as part of JSON response
Issue: this issue was leaking `base_bounty` just like mine.
Disclosed sensitive information: `base_bounty`, `offers_swag`

_This report_ #159526 - **Information leakage of a private program**
Issue: leaking sensitive information of a private program.
Disclosed sensitive information:    `"bug_count":5` `"minimum_bounty":100`  `"soft_launched":true` `"policy":"briefed policy, see attached .txt file"`

It's funny when all the mentioned reports were welcomed, promptly fixed and awarded with monetary rewards, but this report was closed as **informative** saying the behavior is **confusing** and instead of rolling a fix you guys gonna work on wording.

Lets go to HackerOne's program scope and see what it says,

Reports which enumerate already claimed user and program handles. This reveals no sensitive information, regardless of whether the associated profiles are public or private.

True that. only knowing private programs handle reveals no sensitive information. But revealing total bug count, program policy and minimum bounty surely does. these are sensitive information and they should be kept as confidential.

Now lets take a look at this issue to some other kinda similar issues which are fixed and rewarded,

124611 - Disclosure of private programs that have an "external" page on HackerOne

It's funny when all the mentioned reports were welcomed, promptly fixed and awarded with monetary rewards, but this report was closed as informative saying the behavior is confusing and instead of rolling a fix you guys gonna work on wording.

activities.message:
I know you guys receive tons of reports everyday and it takes time to handle all of them.
you guys always tell us to keep patient, it will be really appreciated if response team can have a little patient and at-least allow us to explain before closing an issue to **N/A** or **Informative**. 
It's discouraging when a triaged report directly gets closed as **Informative** or **N/A** without giving researcher a chance to explain a little more.

activities.message:
Hi @faisalahmed,

Looks like there was some misunderstanding with your original report. I'm going to reopen this and ensure somebody looks into it. Sorry for the confusion, and thanks for being patient with us. We do indeed get many, many reports, and it's sometimes hard to figure out if there's an actual valid issue when triaging, especially as all members of our engineering team share triage duties for the @security program. We'll be back in touch soon once somebody has looked into this further.

Thanks!

activities.message:
Hey @faisalahmed,

We're looking in to this, it appears the issue only occurs for the `████` team, due to an inconsistent state in our database. We are figuring out what has caused this, and we'll fix it as soon as we do.

Thank you for your patience and understanding,
@dirk
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @faisalahmed,

We're looking in to this, it appears the issue only occurs for the ████ team, due to an inconsistent state in our database. We are figuring out what has caused this, and we'll fix it as soon as we do.

Thank you for your patience and understanding,
@dirk

activities.message:
Hey @faisalahmed,

We have resolved the inconsistent state in our database. 

We were missing a UNIQUE constraint on a column, which allowed a migration to associate two directory profiles with one hackerone program. This in turn broke some logic in our directory search, leading to exposure of private information. 

Could you please validate that the issue is resolved?

Kind regards,
Dirk
activities.markdown_message:

Kind regards,
Dirk

activities.message:
Hey @dirk,

Confirming the fix.

Thanks
Faisal Ahmed

Hello @dirk,
I have confirmed the issue no longer reproduces for me.
I appreciate you resolving this so quickly :)

activities.message:
@faisalahmed I'd like to redact the team names mentioned in this report, which also means I'll remove the attachments in your original report. Are you okay with this? 

An alternative is disclosing this issue with a limited timeline, which only shows the timeline and a summary.
